Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: What is the reason utxo based smart contracts haven‚Äôt been thought or done by others in industry and what made kmd‚Äôs implementation different as comparison to others?

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: CC layer allows for smart-UTXO.  bind them to previous transactions (e.g. at creation time) and other types of relationships is my guess.  all on-chain.  so where you may have had two tx in the past and been able to make an app that behaves in a similar way, there was no blockchain binding - only an app that could mimic a what-if-we-could-bind-these-transactions-together-with-some-rules.  we now have these rules (conditions) on chain, instead of some random app developer.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: currently the CC contracts are done at the source level

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is linked in and part of the komodod codebase

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: now, it would be possible to make some sort of dynamic linked library to include external code

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this library would have the identical code functions as the current CC contracts. look at faucet.cpp it is 100 lines and not very complex at all

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so whatever language that can create compiled code that can be linked into komodod, those are the languages that can be used. I wouldnt recommend interpreted language

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and the model now is to make a CC contract that can spawn new instances of it via rpc calls. and to limit any repetitive actions and rather be transaction invoked to get runtime. So for assets CC, you do a tx that locks coins/assets into a special address and the other party spends that tx to complete the trade

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: let us not get too abstract

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: let us stick to specific questions on how to do some specific thing.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: I think that will then make it much clearer how it all works

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: start by reading faucet.cpp, then rewards.cpp, then dice.cpp and assets.cpp if you are ready for that level of complexity

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: probably we need someone to make onboarding doc to allow a new dev to come up to speed, however it will require knowing how utxo work. so if we can find pre-existing docs about utxo, a new dev can start with that

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: once you understand utxo, then it will become much clearer. if you dont, it will just be confusing

Author: rexycle#8616
Content: can kmd go multi algo

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: when VRSC does a pull request for verushash, there will be the second one and after that adding new hashalgo will be much simplified

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but if you are talking about multiple algos at the same time... that is open to more attacks as there are multiple diffs to manage. We do have mixed PoW/PoS that can be any percentage from 1% to 100% PoS

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content:
I'm a noob to ETH smart contracts.
Would you say making smart contract on utxo based smart contracts would be easier for developers as compare to making smart contracts on balance based blockchain ?

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content:
As I understand a little, ETH because of not being utxo based looks to be easier. But once a developer gets familiar with the concepts of like
how to make a address
how to generate a raw transaction
how to manage tx inputs/outputs 
that should make them feel easier with crypto conditions ?

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: is my assumption correct ?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it will likely always be easier on a balance based system

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: however with my multipay CC, I will create a balance based system on top of utxo

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: utxo will be harder to deal with, but much much much safer

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: with a balance based system, entire balance is always at risk to a bug

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: with utxo system, only the specific vout funds are at play

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: cool, thanks for clearing James. üôÇ üëç

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: what will be the purpose of multipay CC? What will it solve ?

Content: Could crypto conditions be used for derivative contracts like bitmex so there can be a decentralised bitmex  ?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: theoretically, yes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: after the next round of CC contracts are in place it will become much easier. the only issue is that it needs to be a "cash settled" contract and the "cash" would be the coin for the chain the CC runs on. so it would need to run on a chain with actual value and liquidity

Author: demols#8610
Content: And can barterdex or hyperdex be used to trade contracts ?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: not sure what you mean about trading contracts

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you mean transferring an existing position to another party?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i guess that would be possible if it was implemented, but it seems simpler just to create the same position?

Author: demols#8610
Content: Iff i have a long position someone else does have a short position if i want out of the trade i sell my long position to someone else

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but it is cash settled,so you can just cashout via the blockchain without needing to find someone to buy your position

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that is assuming we can get a blockchain enforced cash settled system working.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so if you can cashout without anybody else, why not do that?

Author: barv#0867
Content: Hi James, I'm trying to set up ms wallets on komodo using addresses from multiple wallets. I bump into problems when signing ("error": "Operation not valid with the current stack size"). probably I am missing a step in the process?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: what is an ms wallet?

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: i guess he means `multisig wallet`

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that is a bit tricky to do as rawtransactions are needed, but there is insufficient details to have any meaningful answer

Author: barv#0867
Content: yes i meant multi signature

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: how are you creating the rawtx to sign?

Author: barv#0867
Content: ./komodo-cli createrawtransaction '[{"txid":"6fd776d3e16cc13ee49f155a67263286ef399f31ec102f0534af38f4c60e0e10","vout":1,"scriptPubKey":"a9147948cffce0053479867bcb6bb033c127b6a1b52387","redeemScript":"522102d43685622601db0b78fdc59769d552829002c8d2b1e2c59d890effa0f1eca54a2102d5c58a6ca89d1608e60eac8c5e844095079114234883ccc699daa68da16ce20e52ae"}]' '{"RAVjxt8igpXPdoLQhRNSQb4LLMLAQS6y8p":0.009}'

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so it is a 2of2?

Author: barv#0867
Content: yep

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then you need to sign it on one of the wallets

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then take the output with one sig and sign it on the other

Author: barv#0867
Content: Yep. So signing on the first walet creates output containing an error

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: well the hex got bigger. use that hex and sign on the second wallet

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and actually I think your redeemscript is not quite right. there was a bug in early bitcoin and to be compatible, the buggy behavior has been preserved. I think you need the normal bitcoin multisig redeemscript

Author: barv#0867
Content: okay. didn't know that

Author: barv#0867
Content: Can I find it somewhere?

Author: barv#0867
Content: But you where right. It worked. no error on the second wallet

Author: barv#0867
Content: Still curious on how to find a better redeem script

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: well if it worked then it is fine

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the first error probably just meant it didnt have all the signatures

Author: barv#0867
Content: Yep. Th efirst error is what I expected indeed

Author: barv#0867
Content: Thanks @jl777c . The sending was successful  too. I'll now setup and test a 2-3.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: just ignore the errors that are just warnings

Content: long term automatic dividends will be the goal, but it wont be for a while as it isnt quite ready for consensus level revshares. however I could see doing a dice dealer type of realtime dividend. or maybe on-demand where you can request a dividend if it is over a threshold amount, for now I am concentrating on the most powerful set of foundational CC contracts so rpc calls can do as much dapps as possible

Content:
general questions to cover:
Q 1: Do I have to have knowledge/understanding of C/C++ to write CryptoConditions contract, since example contracts are written in Komodo source code?
Q 2: Where should a total beginner start from to get started with CryptoConditions Smart Contract from a graduate student's point of view, who have basic understanding of  computers fundamentals and programming.

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: Q 3: How would you compare Bitcoin scripting language Ivy (https://bit.ly/2LoiG8j) with Komodo's CryptoConditions?

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: Q 4: Since CryptoConditions smart contracts are written in compiled languages where about in the future a JavaScript developer can expect something which can help them to code their smart contract DApps using JavaScript based languages?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: A: I fully expect different language bindings to be created based on my C/C++ based code and document.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: A: my upcoming document will be a good place to start

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: A: assembly language vs higher level language with functionality enhancements, ie. not comparable

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: A: using wasm type of approach, JS can be made into a compiled blob, getting it to play nice with the komodod executable will likely require some tricks. And this is core code, so maybe it is best to stay with an actually compiled language

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: Q 5: Will it be possible to make CryptoConditions smart contract which work with only SPV clients ?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: no

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it works at the bitcoin protocol level, so if it is able to work via SPV subset, it would still need to work at the bitcoin protocol level.

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: Q 6: With -ac_cc= what is the recommended value to get a production level blockchain for smart contract dapps ?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: >100 if you want to create a fungible scaling cluster

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: @CHMEX yes, but with qualifiers. see the next answer

Content: The spanning set of rpc contracts possible to be created is based on the rpc extensions the foundational CC contracts have

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: here is the start of my document:

Author: jl777c#5810
Content:
How to write utxo based CryptoConditions contracts for KMD chains
by jl777

This is not the only smart contracts methodology that is possible to build on top of OP_CHECKCRYPTOCONDITION, just the first one. All the credit for getting OP_CHECKCRYPTOCONDITION working in the Komodo codebase goes to @libscott. I am just hooking into the code that he made and tried to make it just a little easier to make new contracts.

There is probably some fancy marketing name to use, but for now, I will just call it "CC contract" for short, knowing that it is not 100% technically accurate as the CryptoConditions aspect is not really the main attribute. However, the KMD contracts were built to make the CryptoConditions codebase that was integrated into it to be more accessible.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content:
Since CC contracts run native C/C++ code, it is turing complete and that means that any contract that is possible to do on any other platform will be possible to create via CC contract.

utxo based contracts are a bit harder to start writing than for balance based contracts. However, they are much more secure as they leverage the existing bitcoin utxo system. That makes it much harder to have bugs that issue a zillion new coins from a bug, since all the CC contract operations needs to also obey the existing bitcoin utxo protocol.

This document will be heavily example based so it will utilize many of the existing reference CC contracts. After understanding this document, you should be in a good position to start creating either a new CC contract to be integrated into komodod or to make rpc based dapps directly.

Chapter 0 - Bitcoin Protocol Basics
Chapter 1 - OP_CHECKCRYPTOCONDITION
Chapter 2 - CC contract basics
Chapter 3 - CC vouts
Chapter 4 - CC rpc extensions
Chapter 5 - CC validation
Chapter 6 - faucet example
Chapter 7 - rewards example
Chapter 8 - assets example
Chapter 9 - dice example
Chapter 10 - lotto example
Chapter 11 - channels example
Chapter 12 - limitless possibilities
Chapter 13 - different languages
Chapter 14 - runtime bindings
Chapter 15 - rpc based dapps
